reviewText:
I enjoy Roy Rogers Movies. He was my Hero when I was growing up.
He truly was The king of The Cowboys

Growing up with Roy in the theater when it was only twenty cents to get in & these movies was seen in Oakdale, California theater that no long is there. Fact is the town of Oakdale has no theater anymore.  Was a great time as a kid to enjoy Roy get the bad guys back then & my wife & I enjoy them just as much now as then.

Heart of the Golden West, 1942 film

The story begins with a herd of Herefords, cattle raised for meat. The Lambert trucking company is there to transport 36 cattle to market. The owner complains about the exorbitant fee. Can the Cattlemen's Association do anything? [Does Barrabee remind you of a character in `Dilbert'?] Roy complains to Lambert about rising charges. Will Barrabee sell out the cattlemen? Roy stops him by suggesting shipping cattle by boat. "Its your idea too." Ross Lambert won't stand for this. The reception doesn't go as expected. "We don't sing hymns." There is a comic greeting for Mr. Popen. "You're dern tootin'." Then Silas Popen gets a warning via an arrow. Next there is a practical joke at the saloon. The horses on the wagon run away, but Roy Rogers catches them. Popen acts scared of this violence.

Roy goes to Lambert's saloon to ask for the missing telegram. [Note the gambling equipment there.] Can they use the steamboat to ship cattle? Lambert reports a fire on the boat, this will draw away the cowboys. There is more comedy in the barn. A horse on fire? Lambert's gang rustles the herd of cattle. The men are warned, they will pursue the rustlers. Popen's choppers fall out. Lambert and his gang plan an ambush; they hide the cattle well. There is a song for entertainment. Mary Lou tells where the cattle are hidden. "Beneath the falls." Lambert catches Mary Lou, but Roy and his men arrive. Lambert's gang is trapped and caught. The storm brings rain. The steamboat owner signs a contract with the cattlemen. The lower costs will enrich the cattlemen of Cherokee City and the ship owner. Will the joke of Smiley and Gabby backfire on them? The paddlewheel steamboat sails on the river. A final song for entertainment.

This story has a lot of comedy for a drama about shipping competition. Some of the comedy is dated. Roy Rogers' movies never lacked for comedy or singing. Was the emphasis on comedy a change from past dramas over economic conflict?

Heart of the Golden West is a very poor transfer - washed out and a ghost image almost like you are watchign an old TV with an indoor antenna. I consider this unacceptable for a DVD.  On the other hand, Come On Rangers is of better quality (though not excellent) and if this is the only  film you care about ,it is worth while. The 2 stars are for Heart of the West.

Republic Pictures presents "HEART OF THE GOLDEN WEST" (16 November 1942) (65 mins/B&W) (Fully Restored/Dolby Digitally Remastered) --- Roy Rogers (born Leonard Slye) moved to California in 1930, at the age of 18 --- played in such musical groups as The Hollywood Hillbillies, Rocky Mountaineers, Texas Outlaws and his own group, the International Cowboys --- In 1934 he formed a group with Bob Nolan and Tim Spencer called "Sons of the Pioneers" --- While in that group he was known as Leonard Slye, then Dick Weston and finally Roy Rogers --- Their songs included "Cool Water" and "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" --- They first appeared in the western "Rhythm on the Range" (1936), starring Bing Crosby --- In 1937 Roy went solo and made his first starring film in 1938, "Under Western Stars" (1938) --- He made almost 100 films --- then came television, "The Roy Rogers Show" (1951) ran on CBS from October 1951 through September 1964.

Under Joseph Kane (Director / Producer), Earl Felton (Screenwriter), Jack A. Marta (Cinematographer), Morton Scott (Musical Direction/Supervision), Richard Van Enger (Editor), Russell Kimball (Art Director) - - - - Our story line and plot, Roy Rogers as a ranch foreman challenges villains who control the overlad shipping of cattle by transporting the animals to market on a riverboat --- Republic Picutres efforts to boost the budgets of Roy's films are evident in this one with its length, production values, music and casting --- Roy had no less than not one, not two buy three sidekicks Smiley Burnette, George "Gabby" Hayes and Bob Nolan leader of the music group The Sons of the Pioneers --- some wonderful tunes, THE RIVER ROBIN -- WHO'S GONNA HELP ME SING -- NIGHT FALLS ON THE PRAIRIE -- COWBOYS AND INDIANS -- RIVER CHANT -- CARRY ME BACK TO OLD VIRGINNY -- OH MY CHILDREN -- EVERY TIME I FEEL THE SPIRIT.

 Wally Wales ...  Henchman Drake

BIOS:
1. Roy Rogers (aka: Leonard Franklin Slye)
Date of Birth: 5 November 1911 - Cincinnati, Ohio
Date of Death: 6 July 1998 - Apple Valley, California

2. George 'Gabby' Hayes (aka: George Francis Hayes)
Date of Birth: 7 May 1885 - Wellsville, New York
Date of Death: 9 February 1969 - Burbank, California

3. Smiley Burnette (aka: Lester Alvin (Smiley) Burnette)
Date of Birth: 18 March 1911 - Summum, Illinois
Date of Death: 16 February 1967 - Encino, California

Check out a new book from Empire Publishing - "THE ROY ROGERS BOOK: A REFERENCE TRIVIA SCRAPBOOK" (Paperback) --- reference trivia scrapbook of Roy Rogers written by Western film historian David Rothel whose accounts of thrilling adventures of B-Western heroes during the Saturday matinees of yesteryear takes us back to our childhood, family and friends --- this is a wish come true, reliving those wonderful years from the past through the pen of David Rothel --- Roy was a top box office draw for Republic Pictures when you went to see him on the big screen, you got exactly what the marquee said --- plenty of thrills, action and hard riding with a song or two thrown in for good measure --- Elected to the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1980 as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers" and elected again in 1988 as Roy Rogers "King of the Cowboys" --- Roy got his horse "Trigger" in 1938 and rode him in every one of his films and TV shows after that --- "Trigger" died in 1965 age of thirty-three --- Roy's dog's name was "Bullet" and appeared in almost as many of his films as "Trigger" did --- Roy's theme song, "Happy Trails", was written by Queen of the West and his wife Dale Evans --- inducted (with his wife Dale Evans) into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1976 --- inducted as a member of the "Sons of the Pioneers into the "Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum" in 1995 just three years before his death --- Don't miss this one --- now appearing on Amazon and Empire Publishing --- Don't hesitate - rush out and pick up your copy today --- Great reading in the days and weeks to come --- I guarantee it!

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc), Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") and Trevor Scott (Down Under DVD Com) as they have rekindled my interest once again for Film Noir, B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on DVD --- stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with musical adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out Amazon where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 65 min on VHS/DVD ~ Republic Pictures ~ (12/01/1991)
Great to watch these westerns again
Roy Rogers, Gabby Hayes, Smiley Burnette and Trigger a must watch, for any fan of B Westerns.
Love Roy!

Ok, it's old fashioned, even a bit silly by today's standards. But it brings back great memories for me. Roy is always the hero. The good guys win, and the bad guys lose. What more do you want? Plus you get to see and hear the Sons of the Pioneers. Good Times all around.
My husband is a huge Roy Rogers fan and loved this movie.
Good old Roy Rogers Movie
I grew up on Roy Rogers. I enjoyed watching the old movies. They were more entertaining and less violent than today's movies.
Roy always rates 4 to 5 stars.  An nice enjoyable hour or so to unwind and channel your inner cowboy pal.  Happy Trails!
I enjoy watching the first film with Smiley Burnette and Gabby Hayes together as Roy's  sidekick as Gene Autry had just entered the US Army Air Force.

Typical western from the 30's or 40's.  Entertaining  and predictable but still entertaining,  Given my choice between Roy Rogers or Gene Autry I prefer Roy.  If you want to watch an old western and watch the good guy rescue the damsel in distress this movie is for you.

very bad vedio and aUDIO

it was the poorest copy I have ever purchased.  I know its was old, but I have bought older movies that were almost perfect.
I have older John Wayne movies that were much better.

This is advertised as a restored classic-The original length of this one was 65 min but only shortened versions of 53 min can be found. As a collector I jumped at this -the jacket has  65min on it, the disc has 65min on it but it is actually only 53 min so a scam by the "film detetective". Is Amazon allowing returns. The second film I purchased is the same "Bells of San Angelo" is advertised and labelled as 78 min but is only 75, the same as all the other releases out there. Do something about this!
Awesome
It's one of the better of the Rogers westerns. Andy Devine is a great sidekick too. Guaranteed entertainment for the entire family.
Great old Roy, more singing than I remember.
Excellent movie.
I like Roy Rogers
Great!

HEART OF THE GOLDEN WEST ('45) ran 56:16 min. and the actual run time is 65 min. No Republic logo at the beginning with a crappy pic but good sound. COME ON RANGERS ('38) ran 53 min. and the actual run time is 57 min. No Republic logo at the beginning, with good sound and a good picture. Alpha Video is the only way to get these two pics!
